hierachy (current and past), as well as the 6 current and past defense diplomats,

among which one respondent mentions the very important element of “building

trust” between partners, or another one says, “establishing honest and friendly re-

lations.” It is interesting that building mutual trust, which is one of the foundations

for good communication, is mentioned extremely rarely. Security, on the other hand,

sees diplomacy as “peaceful political activities” aimed at “creating a positive security

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

environment at national, regional and wider levels.”

Sixteen academic respondents (included within the institution: employer, for

example the Military Academy as part of the Ministry of Defense) see diplomacy as

a “well-prepared and well-thought-out set of foreign policy activities, contacts and

participations aimed at fulfilling the set foreign policy - political agenda of the state”

(from a technical point of view), as well as the “skill of conducting foreign policy for

the promotion of national interests” (essentially).

After all, diplomacy is all that has been said above, with the focus really on

the fact that from a practical point of view, diplomacy is a skill of the subtle and the

capacity to recognize the moment in order to better position and achieve state goals

(or at least the most important part). from them).

From the point of view of the type of institution in which the respondents

work, it is interesting that most of those employed in the civilian segment of the

defense-security sector view diplomacy from the perspective of “peaceful solutions

to crisis-conflict situations” through “dialogue, negotiations and mediation in order

to reach a mutually acceptable solution.” In the same direction is the response of

an employee in the same sector, within the middle management that characterizes

diplomacy (in terms of their work experience) as a tool for “negotiating and resolving

misunderstandings and conflicts in a peaceful way.” This statement is reflected in an

employee in the security - intelligence sector who defines this area as “peaceful po-

litical activity of competent authorities in the foreign policy sense to reach a solution

or cooperation agreement in an engagement that aims to create a positive security

environment in national, regional or wider framework.”

It is noteworthy that fourteen of the 31 respondents who have built their ca-

reers within the Army associate diplomacy directly with security. Thus, for one member

of the Army non-commissioned officer corps, “diplomacy is the strongest weapon of

any country in conducting foreign policy”, while for a senior officer in the Army, this area

is part of the “so-called soft power of a state, a skill that through dialogu... achieves its

own goals of national interest.” For him, diplomacy is also “the skill of using peaceful

means, activities and proceduresthat promote friendship, cooperation, prevent

war and deter states from possible violent and hostile activities.” This is followed

by the prevailing opinion in a number of interviews with active-duty military personnel

that “through diplomacy, goals are achieved without the use of force.”

That experience greatly influences the understanding of diplomacy can be

seen through the answers to this question from employees of institutions that are

not directly related to defense and security. Namely, a middle management respon-

dent employed in the Government of the Republic of North Macedonia, in the field of

economic issues, says about diplomacy: “Diplomacy is associated with international

cooperation between officials, representatives of institutions, organizations or coun-

tries. The main goal of this activity or branch is the establishment of political relations

as well as cooperation in order to improve the relations between the entities in terms

of the economy; by increasing trade; promotion of tourism; road, rail or energy con-

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

nection; as well as promoting cooperation in other areas of social life, culture or even

defense.”

2.2. Specifics of diplomacy

Defining diplomacy on the basis of analysis leads us to think about whether

diplomacy has its specifics in a different field, which are not related to its essence of

practice: its tools, methods, norms, procedures, skills. Focusing not only on the type of

diplomacy, but also on understanding these specifics from the aspect of the institution

in which the respondents work, they were asked the question “what specifics of diplo-

macy are related to your institution and what type of diplomacy is most appropriate

to establish and develop in your institution.” 5

The answers, as expected, vary and are directly related to the institution in

which the respondents work for several years. For example, a local self-government

respondent says that in the activities carried out in the institution at the local level

in which he is employed, there is no strict diplomatic code, but that “attention is paid

to the specifics: cultural, customary, social, economic” of the country in which is the

other local self-government with which it cooperates. The respondent adds that this

local self-government also cooperates with the diplomatic and consular missions on

its territory and that in those contacts and cooperation the national positions and the

national policy of the state towards the representatives of the foreign state are taken

into account. This is an interesting point of view because it shows that diplomacy in

practice has several levels of action, but one unified, the so-called national point of

view, which is in line with the principle of “one voice”.

Respondents from the Army of the Republic of North Macedonia mention

military or defense diplomacy as a form of security diplomacy, but do not distinguish

between these two types of diplomacy. A senior officer in the Army says “defense di-

plomacy with its specifics... should be conducted by military attachés”, and a member

of the non-commissioned officer corps does not distinguish between the Ministry of

Defense and the Army, i.e. puts them under one hat and says: “in the MoD/ARM there

is established military diplomacy.” From the part of the respondents from the Army, it

is interesting to note that with the development of the career and the acquisition of

a higher rank, a distinction begins to be made between these two types of diplomacy

- defense and military. Thus, a respondent from the highest ranks of officers says “in

the institution where I am employed there is military diplomacy which is realized by

appointing and sending personnel as military defense attachés in the diplomatic-con-

sular missions of the country, abroad, who represent the Army through the Ministry

for defense.” A respondent of the same rank says even more directly “diplomacy is

fully applied in both the Ministry of Defense and the Army and covers all segments

according to the nature of the openness of those institutions. Defense diplomacy is

established in the Ministry, while in the Army, military diplomacy.” One of the officers

goes so far as to say that “Ministry of Defense is being correlated with defense diplo-

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

macy whose main goal would be to practice preventive diplomacy.

The specifics of diplomacy, especially in the field of defense and security, are

really clear to the staff of these institutions. Thus, 26 respondents employed in the

Ministry of Defense (excluding military personnel), talk about the specifics of defense

diplomacy. This is the case for the seven respondents employed in the Ministry of

Interior. It is interesting that 20 percent of the civilian respondents in the Ministry of

Defense and the respondents from the Ministry of Interior point to the specificity of

the diplomatic action vis-a-vis the sensitivity of the information in this sector. Thus,

one respondent in relation to the specifics of diplomacy states “the use of securi-

ty-politically sensitive information to argue positions”, while one respondent from the

intelligence and security sector says that “a subset of diplomatic relations requires a

set of skills - high professionalism, intelligence, experience, integrity, expertise and a

fully and highly developed security culture due to the specifics of the security-defense

sector, especially from the aspect of protection against unwanted leakage of confi-

dential information.” From the answers, it can be deduced that all respondents from

the intelligence and security sector in this part of the interview mention “trust” as an

important segment that must be built for success in the conduct of defense diplomacy,

especially because of the possible exchange of sensitive information whether or not

they are explicitly listed as classified.

The five respondents from the Government, for example, relate the specifics of

diplomatic activity to their sectors: economy, European integration and the like. Thus,

“economic diplomacy is the most appropriate part that can and should be developed

within the Government, as a cap of the executive branch in the country. Economic

diplomacy is a complex continuous process that should be carried out by all ‘actors’ at

this level regardless of their direct or indirect connection with the economy” and the

respondent connects this claim with “the essence of the needs of ordinary citizens,

which are of economic nature.” Respondent, former employee of the Secretariat for

European Affairs, on the other hand, points to the specificity of conducting diplomacy

related to the Euro-integration process, as a segment divided between the Secretar-

iat, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Government (generally), where it refers to

a kind of rivalry between these institutions. “Secretariat for European Affairs, as an

avant-garde cell in Macedonia with a leading role in the European integration process,

not only leads in contacts (not so much diplomatic, but more bureaucratic) with the

European Union, but from the very beginning is in a latent competitive relationship

with the MFA (which Law plays a primary role in the foreign policy of the country,

including in relation to the EU), on which body will have the primacy in the European

integration process, especially in terms of merit for certain national successes. In this

context, it distinguishes “two relatively adequate types of diplomacy in the SEA: bu-

reaucratic diplomacy taking place largely in the orbit of an evolutionary supranational

structure such as the EU... and public diplomacy as a more sophisticated concept of

public communications and public relations in the domain of European integration.”

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

2.3. Correlation, institutionalization and defense diplomacy

The systematic elaboration of the defense diplomacy can be seen through the

way of conceptualizing the interviews with the respondents in the research. Namely,

after defining the specifics of diplomacy in the context of the institution where the

respondents work, it is quite natural to take the next step, or to determine the re-

lationship, the correlation between defense diplomacy and the relevant institution.

The phrase “without security there is no economic development” indicates that any

institution that is not directly related to defense diplomacy, however, should have

minimal knowledge of it, in order to properly articulate key defense messages that

go in favor of diplomatic efforts for the realization of state goals in any area of action.

In order to determine the current situation related to the institutions where the re-

spondents come from, they were asked the question: “Is there a correlation between

the institution in which you work and the so-called ‘Defense diplomacy”? If yes, what

is it, if not, why does it not exist and if it does, will it contribute to the advancement,

strengthening of the security and safety of the state and its citizens?”

Respondents from the Parliament of the Republic of North Macedonia say

that the connection between the defense diplomacy and the legislative power in the

country is strong. “Certainly there is an appropriate correlation between parliamen-

tary and defense diplomacy. The connection is within the legislative, representative

and oversight function of the Assembly,” said one of the respondents from the senior

management of this, the highest legislative body.

The institution President of the Republic of North Macedonia has a direct

impact on military diplomacy, something that is emphasized in the answers of the

respondents from this institution. “According to the Law on Defense, the President

appoints the highest military representatives of the country abroad. Hence, it directly

and immediately influences the country’s military diplomacy. In that way, it directly

affects the improvement of the security and safety of the citizens and the whole

system,” says a respondent employed in the institution.

From the aspect of group determination, it can be said that within the minis-

tries, the answers of the respondents indicate that defense diplomacy is a well-known

activity. Of course, most of these respondents come from the Ministries of Defense

- Security or Foreign Affairs and it is quite natural for the staff to be familiar with the

concept and goals of defense diplomacy.

It is interesting that all respondents, employees of the Ministry of Defense, indi-

cate that this Ministry is the bearer of this type of diplomacy. “The Ministry of Defense

of the Republic of North Macedonia is a leading institution in defense diplomacy and in

coordination with the President, the Government and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs,

and through defense - diplomatic methods and techniques, contributes to achieving

national interests,” said one respondent from the middle management in the Ministry.

On the other hand, the group of respondents from the executive branch, but this time

from the Ministry of Interior, believe that their institution is related to defense diplo-

macy, and at the same time did not mentioned the Ministry of Defense as the carrier.

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

Additionally, some of these respondents mention “police attachés” as a counterpart

to their colleagues in the military segment, who would be of great help in developing

police cooperation. Thus, a respondent from the Ministry of Interior says: “In order to

improve cooperation and communication at the interstate level in the field of security, it

would be most appropriate to establish a network of defense diplomacy through police

attachés in neighboring countries, but also in countries with which we have the most

intensive cooperation.” Her colleague, a respondent from the same ministry, agrees

with her, pointing out that “in our diplomatic practice there is still no institute of police

attaché that would be in function of achieving certain important directions in the field

of international cooperation and engagement.” “The ministry has its liaison officers in

various international or regional initiatives, institutions, organizations (Interpol, Sepka,

Marri, etc.).” This respondent also raises the question whether the Ministry of Interior

is even considering the topic of increasing the intensity of international cooperation

in the field of security, saying that “objectively, at the level of the ministry has not yet

opened a topic in terms of ways and the modalities for the use of diplomacy and how it

would be conceptually or primarily strategic. This claim was followed by a respondent

from the same ministry who says that “unfortunately, the leadership in the Ministry

does not sufficiently recognize it, nor do they attach a high place to defense diplomacy.”

It is interesting to note the opinion of a respondent from the foreign diplomatic

corps confirms the direction mentioned by the Macedonian police respondents: “police

diplomacy is a new and advanced version of defense diplomacy in which the focus is

on the police force, instead of the military and military elements,” he said.

Compared to the civilian element of the defense and the respondents from

the Ministry of Interior, the uniformed army members almost completely connect

this issue with the military attachés, as a segment of the defense diplomacy. Of note

are two opinions from high-ranking army officers who have two completely opposing

views: one explicitly stating that “there is no defense diplomacy”, but military attachés

within the Ministry of Defense, and the other who has a more comprehensive view,

which except what the Ministry of Defense puts at the center, as the bearer of defense

diplomacy, also includes a kind of “informal diplomacy”, which refers to every single

individual who has a chance as part of an international activity - course, training,

exercise, schooling or similarly, in the form of a kind of ambassador, to represent our

country and contribute to the development of its reputation, certainly in accordance

with the general and generally accepted foreign policy of the country.

2.4. Features of defense diplomacy

As already defined, urban diplomacy is a much broader concept than what is

called military diplomacy, because it includes its goals and objectives, but extends to

the limits of building mutual trust, preventing crises and resolving conflicts, as well

as dialogue in the defense context, and the development of bilateral and multilateral

defense cooperation.

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

In the context of the research, we begin the understanding of defense diplo-

macy with the most affected, defense diplomats, or defense attachés who serve or

have served our country in countries in the region, but also with our main strategic

partners and NATO-Alliance headquarters. The question asked to the respondents

was: “To what extent are you familiar with the specifics of defense diplomacy? If you

consider yourself an expert, how much does its specifics make it essential in strength-

ening, promoting security and stability? If you have relatively little knowledge, what

is your general thinking as a person with extensive experience and work experience,

regarding defense diplomacy and the need for its existence and development?“

“Well-established defense cooperation, supported by good bilateral relations

at the state level, greatly contributes to strengthening and promoting security and

stability,” is the answer of our currently active defense attaché to this question. In this 5

context, the explanation goes that the defense attaché is the one who coordinates

the cooperation in the field of defense and the armed forces: joint exercises, training

and education, but also joint participation in international peacekeeping missions. As

our attaché states, a crucial element in the success of the work of a defense attaché

is the personal engagement, the established contacts and the gained mutual trust.

Our former attaché in one of the most important allied countries says “defense

diplomacy is of the utmost importance in creating alliances and partnerships. It is an

adaptation of the concept of the use of ‘soft’ force that can influence the strategic

thinking of other countries.” That reality encompasses challenges of various kinds is

also shown by the opinion of one of our former representatives in an international

organization who says: “In the past, defense diplomacy was expressed in conveying

the views of defense authorities, who in some cases were not competent enough for

the functions they performed,” adding that the impression is that in certain segments,

only party interests of the ruling party were implemented, and not the state or defense

interests.

The importance of defense diplomacy as an integral part of a country’s for-

eign policy is very plastically conveyed by answering the same question through the

example: “The basis of US foreign policy are the three pillars: diplomacy, development

and defense (3D - Diplomacy, Development, Defense) and the representatives of those

three pillars are the core of each of this country’s representations: the ambassador

and his legal adviser, the head of USAID and the defense attaché.”

Defense diplomacy, says the same government official, may be a tool for pre-

serving world civilization and natural resources, given that today the world is multipolar,

and countries have huge military capabilities, i.e. weapons from both conventional and

unconventional nature.

Interesting is the perception of one of the respondents with extremely great expe-

rience working in Alliance commands who makes a distinction between the under-

standing of a diplomat, as opposed to a military representative (or defense attache).

In the first case we are talking about the so-called “General practitioner”, while for the

second “subject matter expert”.

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

The academic community views the question of the specifics of defense diplo-

macy in a more systematic way: “The meaning and success of defense diplomacy largely

depends on the military-economic capacity, strategic goals and systematic approach

of the one who performs this activity.” Smaller countries, according to the respondent,

can hope for some significant benefit only if they seriously and systematically approach

building closer relations with key partners and allies, exchange relevant security-intel-

ligence data and promote their own country and advance national interests through

missions for capacity building, security sector reform and military training.

2.5. Defense vs. military diplomacy: differences and similarities, (respon-

dents’ thinking)

If we talk about the differences between military and defense diplomacy,

the practice says that the generally accepted opinion among practitioners is that

defense diplomacy conducts international cooperation in the field of defense, i.e.

that it has a wider range and includes all resources. Military diplomacy, on the other

hand, is an integral part of it, but it is focused on the so-called “Military-to-military”

cooperation and is dependent on defense cooperation. Of course, the terminological

division is made according to the persons who conduct one or the other diplomacy,

military diplomacy is conducted by military persons, and defense by the highest and

lowest leadership in the Ministry of Defense, covering various aspects in the field of

defense, military element, or broader defense conglomerate which includes economy,

democracy, human rights, etc.

The following question is in that direction: “Defense versus military diplomacy

- differences and similarities? Your opinion,” to which almost unified answer was given

by the respondents employed in the ministries: defense diplomacy is a broader term

than military diplomacy. “Defense diplomacy is a wide range of areas, measures and

activities that include various areas, various state institutions that are important to

defense as a function. Military diplomacy is more moderate, more specific and more

purposeful. It is an extended arm of defensive diplomacy and regulates the details,

specifics and details of its specific domain in order to achieve the higher goal, which

again regulates and sets defense diplomacy,” said one intelligence-security respondent.

This is followed by another opinion which says that defense diplomacy is broader in

its scope than the military and that it has nothing to do with the background of prac-

titioners, whether they are civilians or military personnel. It is interesting that within

this group of respondents, those coming from the Ministry of Defense consider that

it is a function of the defense, not including other institutions in the security sector.

Unlike them, more than half of the interviewed members of the Ministry of Interior

explicitly mention this Ministry as part of the system of defense diplomacy.

In addition, what can be noted is that in the vast majority of interviewees, what-

ever the connection in the context of supremacy, there is always the opinion that these

two types of diplomacy complement each other in meeting state goals. “One thing is

clear, they function with the highest degree of synergy,” said one defense respondent.

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

Respondents from the Assembly believe that there is a cause-and-effect

relationship between defense and military diplomacy. It is interesting because of the

specific answer to point out that one respondent from the Assembly of the Republic

of North Macedonia, with many years of experience especially related to defense indi-

cates that defense and military diplomacy are fundamentally different, but in terms of

functionality are complementary. “In democratic societies, a clear distinction is made

between defense and military diplomacy, by holders and competencies. Defense di-

plomacy is led by the civilian government, and military diplomacy by military experts,

under the supervision of the civilian government,” he said.

The explanation so far has been confirmed by foreign experts, respondents in

the research process from several continents. For example, one of them, with over 40

years of experience in the defense system of a European country, says that “in coun- 5

tries with a developed democratic multi-party parliamentary system, there is civilian

control of the armed forces and accordingly the military exercises its competence

through the Ministry of Defense, as part of the Government.” Accordingly, he points

out, the notion of defense diplomacy is broader than the notion of military diplomacy.

He points out that some of the policies of the defense diplomacy are realized through

the international activities implemented by the military. And these activities are

planned, organized, coordinated and with a single goal: achieving a favorable position

of the state in international relations.

In order to complete the view of the respondents related to this issue, it is

necessary to see the opinion of the respondents from the uniformed composition

of the Army of the Republic of North Macedonia, as directly involved in the defense

system.

All 31 respondents “in uniform” believe that military diplomacy is a very im-

portant element for the country, in achieving foreign policy goals. It is interesting that

the persons interviewed have senior officer ranks and are younger in age, without

exception indicating that defense diplomacy is broader than military diplomacy, i.e.

it includes military diplomacy.

This, in turn, is not the case with the respondents who have the highest

ranks of officers, and are older. A concrete example of this is the following opinion:

“Are there any differences between defense and military diplomacy? Definitely yes!

There is a big difference. Military diplomacy is a broader term that includes gathering

intelligence in the countries sent for the needs of our country’s defense, as well as

achieving international cooperation with the armed forces of the country where the

military attaché is deployed.“

A part of this group of respondents also thinks that military diplomacy today

has de facto grown into defense diplomacy.

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY
2.6. Defense diplomacy in the context of modern challenges for the country

Considering that most of the respondents are from our country (86 out of

91), it was extremely important in the research process to determine how so far, ac-

cording to the experience of the respondents, foreign diplomacy has been included in

the most important state events throughout the years of Macedonian independence.

The question that was asked is: “Which events in Macedonia from independence until

today would you single out as events that demanded and were the subject of defense

diplomacy? How did defense diplomacy affect the end of these challenges, which

also affected the establishment and development of the security and stability of the

country?”

According to the quantitative analysis, the majority of respondents associate

the activities of defense diplomacy with negative developments in the country, such

as the 2001 conflict, the Kosovo crisis, and illegal migration. On the other hand, 19

percent of the answers refer to the country’s Euro-Atlantic integration, i.e. the efforts

for membership in NATO and the European Union.

The elaboration on how the defense diplomacy affected a certain conflict situ-

ation can be clearly and concretely seen in the answer of a respondent, an employee at

the Ministry of Interior who says: “I single out the crisis of 2001 and the migrant crisis

of 2015/16, in a way that through negotiation, communication and cooperation with

external factors, the establishment and development of the security and stability of

the country has been achieved.” In relation to the same crisis (the 2001 conflict), one

respondent puts the thesis differently. He says: “the answer is the crisis in 2001, but

then we were consumers of defensive - diplomatic activities of other countries.” It is

interesting that a respondent, employed in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, mentions

the crisis during the period of independence, as a successful process of conducting

defense diplomacy (Gligorov-Agjic Agreement, from 1991 for the withdrawal of the

Yugoslav People’s Army from Macedonia) which enabled without a single human life to

fulfill the centuries-old goal of the Macedonian people - an independent Macedonian

state.

Simply, as one respondent from the middle management in the Ministry of

Defense says, “there is no event that does not affect defense diplomacy, and examples

are the Kosovo crisis, the accommodation of allied forces and refugees, the resolution

of the internal conflict in 2001 ...

The prevailing opinion is that in the context of the country’s membership

in NATO, as a political strategic goal and effort of the entire diplomatic apparatus,

including the part of the defense (conducting defense diplomacy), defense diplomats

were successful in their task. One respondent from the intelligence-security sector

says that the implementation of defense and military diplomacy in the Republic in the

context of the political strategy for meeting the criteria for full NATO membership

was permanent, consistent and long-term.

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

2.7. Defense diplomacy for the purpose of developing security

and defense today

“Diplomacy and defense are not substitutes for each other. “Each one of them,

individually, will fail,” said US President John F. Kennedy in 1961. Each new era brings

new security challenges, and today’s reality, in the 21st century, is no exception. What

may separate the 21st century from the 20th is the multilayered, complex, and dynamic

nature of the security challenges with which nations are facing. One of the main areas

that has changed its traditional role is defense diplomacy, which according to the

experience of the respondents in the research offers a subtle, low-risk way of solving

security challenges. Defense diplomacy through “soft power” can build partnerships,

but also create and maintain strategic influence in favor of its own foreign policy, while

at the same time helping to “break down” tensions and avoid conflicts. As one of the

key players in achieving foreign policy goals, defense policy must be synchronized with

other levels of state power: political relations, culture, social dynamics, trade, econo-

my. With “one word” the approach of one voice, i.e. the so-called “whole government

approach” can only reinforce the message conveyed through defense policy.

From today’s perspective, membership in the Alliance, the finally completed

three-decade process of full membership, is a process that requires active defense

diplomatic diplomacy.

Exactly this process is one of the most frequently mentioned when interview-

ing the respondents employed in the ministries. After the formalization of the full

membership, the process of staffing, positioning and functioning in accordance with

the established rules and procedures in the Alliance itself begins. “Apart from NATO

membership and active participation in European defense and security policy, defense

diplomacy should be actively involved in the creation of NATO defense planning, global

security and capacity building in the context of the Alliance’s three core functions:

collective defense, crisis management and cooperative security,” said one respondent.

The interviewed members of the armed forces also mention the regional

challenges that require attention and action by the defense diplomacy. “Special en-

gagement of the defense diplomacy in this period should be in the Western Balkans

region, especially in the negotiations between Kosovo and Serbia, in order to prevent

endangering the security and stability of the region. Particular attention should be

paid to defining an agreement that will be acceptable to both parties and that will not

cause border changes and jeopardize the stability of the region. As a NATO member,

Macedonia will now be exposed to a greater degree of defense diplomacy by Greece,

which will seek to become Macedonia’s strategic partner in the Balkans in order to

squeeze out Turkish influence. That is why our defense diplomacy needs to be profes-

sionalized and strengthened. Defense diplomacy consists not only of detached offices

and defense attachés, but also of the domestic pool of competent and professional

experts,” said a respondent with many years of experience in defense and experience

related to defense diplomacy.

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

Respondents from the intelligence-security sector agree, however, that to-

day defense diplomacy must take into account new security risks: terrorism, hybrid

threats, cyber-threats, extremism and illegal migration. “Hybrid and cyber-threats,

violent extremism and terrorism of all kinds, organized crime of all kinds, refugee

crisis, foreign (hostile) intelligence services, fake news, growing arms trends, natural

disasters, technical disasters, epidemics, global climate threat, degradation of the

environment, economic - political instability: all this must be influenced through the

tools of defense diplomacy,” said a respondent employed in this sector.

2.8. Human resources and defense diplomacy

With the dynamization of international relations after the end of the Cold War,

diplomatic activities, meetings, contacts, coordination were also intensified. Diplomats,

unable to consult their base whenever and wherever action is needed, had to adapt

quickly and efficiently to the situation and find the most appropriate solution, to make

the most adequate decision that would have the best possible effect on their country

and its foreign policy goals, at every level of action: closest neighborhood, regionally

and globally.

That is why the approach of the state to its diplomacy is of the utmost im-

portance, which must be fully prepared to perform its function in support of its own

state. And, in order to achieve this internal (from the aspect of diplomacy) goal, the

management of knowledge, their real use, the real placement of the persons vs. tasks

and jobs is of utmost importance.

“Knowledge is a fluid mix, a mix of experience, values, contextual information

and expert insights that provides a framework for evaluating and incorporating new

experiences and information,” said Davenport and Prusak243. They add that in diplo-

macy, probably more than in the business sector, knowledge is both the basis and the

product of the thinking process.

Jovan Kurbalija, on the other hand, says that knowledge as a combination

of information, experience and intuition is what enables a diplomat to behave ap-

propriately in unpredictable situations.244 In this regard, it should be noted that the

knowledge of diplomats occurs in many forms, from the general knowledge gained

through formal education throughout life, upgraded by specific knowledge in the field

of international relations and international law, then special diplomatic training that

drastically would help in dealing with the unpredictable within the service, knowledge

gained through experience, knowledge of procedures.

The evolution of the diplomatic service inevitably requires the evolution of

diplomacy, especially in the context of diplomatic training.

243 Davenport, T.H. and Prusak, L. (1998): Working Knowledge: How Organizations Manage

What They Know. Harvard Business School Press, Boston, p.5.

244 Kurbalija, J. (1999): Diplomacy in the age of information technology, Palgrave Macmillan,

London.

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

The significance of the abovementioned for diplomacy, in a general sense, can

be reflected in the context of defense diplomacy. The practitioners of the Macedonian

defense diplomacy are basically not “career” diplomats. On the contrary, if we take as

an example the defense attachés, as part of the system of defense diplomacy, we will

see that these are uniformed persons, officers with higher rank (lieutenant colonel,

colonel), who in their career have completed high military, but also additional military

and civilian education (School of National Defense, Command-Staff Academy), i.e.

schools that prepare them for staff duties. Of course, within the educational activity,

the Ministry of Defense, in cooperation with the allies, provides additional education

in the field of diplomacy, which is especially important in the context of sending “real

people to the right positions”.

Precisely given that the state, society, institutions in North Macedonia still 5

face “infantile problems” and shortcomings related to the essence of this maxim – “real

people in the right positions’, their career guidance (career development) and their

positioning according to what they are trained for, no less, no more at the expense

of the citizens and the state they should represent, but also the policy of (not) filling

the especially important positions that are part of the network of defense diplomacy,

the respondents who were part of the research had the opportunity to answer the

following question: “What should be the capacity (human, material, individual) of the

representation of North Macedonia in NATO, as the so-called “hub” of Macedonia’s

defense diplomacy?”

Most affected are the respondents from the Ministry of Defense and the Army

of the Republic of North Macedonia, as well as those from the Ministry of Foreign Afff-

fairs which have a more comprehensive view of the capacity of our defense diplomacy,

especially within the Alliance. The respondents, with extensive experience working in

the Parliament, say that the staff that will be sent needs to be professional, skilled and

properly educated, but they do not give a large number of details, just as the employees

of the President of the country point out. Interviewees from other state bodies, other

state administration bodies, local self-government institutions, the private sector and

respondents from foreign countries give the answer that they are not familiar enough

with the matter in order to be able to give an appropriate opinion.

“For our representation in NATO, the capacity should be as much as necessary

to rationally and effectively fulfill the obligations. I believe that all facilities should

be above all highly professional, professional, with knowledge of NATO processes,

language fluent, protocol-educated and persons with integrity,” said a respondent

from the Ministry of Defense with experience in defense diplomacy. He adds that “in

Brussels and Washington, the rank of the first persons must be the highest, because

of the attitude of the host and because of the attitude of the other representatives.

If the rank is lower than, conditionally speaking, provided then the impact and signif-

icance of that entity will be less and less visible. People with insufficient experience,

without language fluency, required rank and maturity is a recipe for failure, and thus

a negative advertisement for the state “.

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

He and most of the respondents from the Ministry of Defense point out that

a pool of competent staff, professionals and experts must be established from where

those who will be part of the defense-diplomatic system of the country will be se-

lected. Exactly in the context of the “pool of experts”, one respondent concludes that

“unfortunately, in the past we have not been able to create a group of people through

trainings, seminars, courses who could potentially be our future military-diplomatic

representatives “.

That the defense - diplomatic network can not be greater than the capacity of

the state indicate more respondents, employed in the ministries. “The capacity in each

of the mentioned aspects should be proportional to the undertaken obligations and

in accordance with the objective possibilities of the state. This is especially important

when it comes to dimensioning the defense and military representatives within the

available human, financial and material capacities of the state,” said a respondent

from the Ministry of Defense.

Over fifty percent of respondents employed by the Ministry of Defense, the

Ministry of Interior and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs considered that defense-dip-

lomatic staff must be staff with previous experience in an international environment

(for example, respondents from the Ministry of Defense mention that in the context

of the required experience there should be participation in peacekeeping missions of

which our country is a part - whether the mission in Afghanistan, previously ISAF, today

“Resolute Support”, whether the mission in Lebanon, UNIFIL, the mission in Bosnia

and Herzegovina, Althea, or the new missions that include members of the Army of

the Republic of North Macedonia, the KFOR forces in Kosovo and the mission in the

Central African Republic.

These respondents, who for obvious reasons are the most competent to answer

the question, say that it is not only necessary for those who are directed to defense -

diplomatic duty to show professionalism and knowledge, but that it is also necessary

for the colleagues they work with every day, in the parent institution, in the country.

“Those tasked with carrying out tasks in the NATO mission need to be experts in their

field with a high degree of professionalism and integrity and appropriate training.

They should have at their disposal all the necessary resources, as well as constant

contact with quality and dedicated professionals from the home countryy with

whom they will work together in the implementation of activities of state interest,”

said a respondent from the Ministry of Interior.

Perhaps the most explicit answer was given by a respondent who was directly

involved in the planning process of the North Macedonia Representation in NATO, who

said: “The capacity should be adequate in order to perform all tasks and responsibilities

arising from our membership in the Alliance. At NATO headquarters, the scope of work

of the Committees themselves dictates the profiling of the Mission (or Delegation as

a possible name in the future). It is planned that the MoD and the Army will send 15

people to our Mission in NATO, 11 people military personnel in the Military Represen-

tation and 4 people in the Defense Section. In addition to the staff from the Ministry

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

of Foreign Affairs, Agency for national security, Directorate for Security of Classified

Information and Crisis management center have sent or will send their own staff to

the Mission. “Allied Command Operations (ACO), or more precisely its headquarters

(SHAPE) in Mons-Belgium, envisages the Army sending 6 military personnel and in

the Allied Command Transformation (ACT) in Norfolk, USA, sending 1 person “.

2.9. Relationship between defense diplomacy and protocol

There may not be a better illustration of the connection between diplomacy

(including defense diplomacy) and the protocol from the diplomatic protocol, which as

an individual exists in each of the countries and is naturally set up within the Ministry

of Foreign Affairs.

In order to obtain the opinions and thoughts of the respondents, who de fac-

to mostly have vast experience in their field of work, they were asked the following

question: “What is the connection of defense diplomacy with other relevant specific

areas such as the protocol and protocol rules, regulations and procedures?”

The respondent from the private sector (with exceptional knowledge in the

field of protocol), and at the same time an educator in that field says: “One part of what

is called diplomacy is the diplomatic protocol and here we can not isolate the defense

diplomacy. Every international interaction includes rules of protocol and etiquette,

because diplomatic protocol is not just about the ceremonial part, as it was in the

past, but also many other established norms of conduct that need to be respected.”

In fact, that the protocol rules and procedures are inextricably linked to defense

diplomacy and diplomacy in general, we can see through examples directly related

to our country, such as the Ohrid Framework Agreement, the Prespa Agreement, a

number of visits by extremely important world politicians. the recent visit of the leader

of the Catholic Church, etc. (described in Chapter Five, the Protocol and Defense Diplo-

macy of the Republic of North Macedonia, point three - The role of defense diplomacy

and the protocol in achieving the security of the Republic of North Macedonia).

Defense diplomacy is not a separate entity that is not related to other relevant

specific areas, such as protocol and protocol rules. In fact, one of the respondents from

the academic field points out that “the engagement of the diplomatic representatives

is support of the mission according to the rule 30/30/30, ie 30 percent work on dip-

lomatic tasks, 30 percent protocol and 30 percent intelligence and security issues.”

“Protocol is an integral and indispensable part of defense diplomacy”, “proto-

col rules, processes and procedures are part of diplomatic communication, including

communication in defense diplomacy.” For practitioners in the field of protocol, the

connection is direct – “diplomacy is based on norms of conduct, negotiation, proce-

dures that are intertwined with the protocol. The protocol procedures of diplomats

are very important to convince the foreign partner of our seriousness, commitment

and perspective for cooperation.” This is complemented by the opinion of another

practitioner in this field that “the establishment of international norms for the award

of military honors during official visits at the highest state level is a way to regulate

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

international relations and mutual respect, and any inconsistency can be interpreted as

disrespect and insult to the other.” “Protocol mistakes can negatively affect relations

between states and thus contribute to strengthening the possibility of an interstate

conflict,” said one respondent.

Generally interpreted, the essence of this process is diplomacy, the message,

but the whole package makes the protocol and that is why there is a complete in-

tertwining between diplomacy and protocol rules. Or, “protocol and diplomacy are a

functional whole. Knowledge of protocol and protocol rules, regulations and procedures

by diplomacy personnel, including military-diplomatic personnel in defense diplomacy,

is a reflection of the professionalism and institutional structure of the system.” This is

followed by the opinion of a respondent, a longtime practitioner in the field of defense

diplomacy who points out that in the period of pre-preparation, one of the mandato-

ry topics of processing not only for the staff who will perform the task, but also the

accompanying family is the protocol, protocol activities and etiquette behavior.

2.10. Protocol - a separate area or incorporated unit in diplomacy

One of the crucial set of questions to which the respondents answered was the

impact, i.e. the connection of the protocol with security. First, the question is whether

that connection exists, and then whether the connection is strong and direct or not,

and how it is implemented.

Respondents were asked the question: “What is your knowledge of the pro-

tocol? Is the protocol an individual area or is it related and perhaps incorporated with

other related areas such as diplomacy or defense diplomacy and why?”, which would

initially determine the respondents’ knowledge of the protocol area, and then relevant

answers on whether the protocol can be considered an individual area or an area that

functions incorporated within diplomacy.

Although the vast majority of respondents have some knowledge of what the

protocol means, what its place is, and its connection to other areas, practically a few

have worked as protocol specialists.

Again, starting from the answer of the respondent from the private sector, who

is directly involved in the field of protocol, we can see that the true connoisseurs of the

protocol point to the absolute impossibility of seeing this area as an “isolated system”.

Namely, the respondent says: “I know the protocol well and I work in this field. It can

absolutely not be seen as an isolated segment of diplomacy, but it encompasses many

other practical segments such as organizational and leadership skills, detail-taking

skills, teamwork, courtesy, tact, resourcefulness and calmness.“

A respondent from the ranks of employees in the ministries, currently part of

the middle management staff, directly connected with the defense diplomacy, puts

the protocol on the pedestal, as an area with which all other related elements are

connected.

“The protocol plays an important role in presenting an institution, especially

when it comes to diplomatic affairs. The first impression is crucial. Arranging, timely

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

undertaking and anticipation of all subsequent steps are key to timely and proper

implementation of an activity. “All other areas must be linked and incorporated into

the protocol for the activities to go as planned,” said the respondent.

“Protocol is an interdisciplinary field. It provides functional integrity with other

areas such as diplomacy, i.e. defense diplomacy. The protocol is simply a link between

the rules of the game and the goals that need to be achieved”, said a ministry staff

member. That area is not only related, points out an extremely large number of respon-

dents, but also complements diplomacy, shapes it, sets it in frames. A respondent from

the academic field also speaks about those frameworks, who says that protocol and

diplomacy are inseparable, in order to organize, agree on terms, personnel, location,

directions and actions, security procedures, levels of diplomatic representation...

“The protocol is a system that gives diplomacy guidelines, rules of conduct, ethics, 5

morals and weight. The protocol is a mechanism to avoid chaos, the protocol is the

conductor of the orchestra,” said a respondent from the ranks of officials employed

in the ministries.

For one respondent, protocol is an “individual area”, and the view stems from

the view that diplomacy is essentially an activity that is invisible, at the expense of

protocol activities that are visible and public. Contrary to this opinion, a respondent

with 25 years of experience in the field of diplomacy says: “The protocol is an area that

can not function individually, but it is a segment in which all information on diplomatic

representation at home and abroad are united.”

She adds that it is extremely important to have a broad knowledge of many

areas, especially the previous interstate cooperation, customs and traditions of the

host country.

2.11. Specifics of the protocol relevant to defense diplomacy

The protocol as an area is inextricably linked to diplomacy, and thus to de-

fense diplomacy. This is the position of the majority of respondents in the survey,

respondents who in large numbers have over 15 years of work experience in state

administration bodies: from the Government, Parliament and Ministries, all the way

to local self-government.

That thread connecting protocol and diplomacy vs. protocol and defense

diplomacy are not different or parallel, but overlap and therefore it can be said that

the specifics of the protocol in the context of diplomacy or defense diplomacy do not

differ from each other.

“Diplomatic protocol requires its own precision and respect for internation-

al standards. Given the fact that defense diplomacy aims to achieve bilateral and

multilateral cooperation through defense resources, the protocol fulfills its function

here as well. Knowledge of military ceremonies, the specificity of the correspondence,

ranking and transmission in the defense structures is also the basis,” said a respondent

from the private sector. It makes perhaps the only distinction in the specifics of the

protocol in the context of the defense sphere, and that is the knowledge of military,

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

i.e. defense specifics, such as military protocol and military ceremonies that differ to

some extent from the characteristics of the basic diplomatic ceremony.

The majority of the respondents, in terms of specifics, mainly mention the

knowledge of the history, culture, customs, social rules and norms of the host country,

which is seemingly quite easy and well known, but when it comes to cultures and soci-

eties closer to us, as European. But the world is full of traditions different from those

that are part of the traditions of “Western civilization”. In the Middle East, for example,

shoes are taken off before entering the house, the left hand is never used for greeting

or passing, it is always eaten with the right hand only, it does not sit cross-legged, the

toe is not raised as a sign that something is wrong. For illustration, in India, the term

“time is money” is unknown, they never say categorically “no”, but “we will see”, etc.245

Each of these cultures has its own peculiarities that must be taken into account by

diplomats, including in the field of defense.

In this context, a group of respondents from the employees of the ministries

mention exactly these elements, and one of them says: “knowledge of the language

of the country in which one resides, knowledge and respect for the history, culture

and specifics of the country, the capacity to a multicultural, multiethnic, multi-con-

fessional environment along with good interpersonal communication are imperative

for any good diplomat. These are, in fact, the specifics of the protocol!“

The same group of respondents is of the opinion that in addition to knowing

the social, cultural and moral norms, it is necessary to know (to some extent) the

legal norms, because they are an “important factor” in the proper establishment of

diplomatic relations.

The respondents from the ranks of the Army, in the vast majority point out

the need to know the ways to maintain secrecy in one area of operations, which is

certainly a specificity of protocol and diplomacy.

What is interesting about this category of respondents is that almost without

exception everyone lists the following elements as specifics of the protocol - accuracy,

precision, principle, equality, discipline, reciprocity.

2.12. The protocol in the institutions

Having in mind that the working organizations from where the respondents

come from are quite diversified, through the set of questions within the interviews –

“In the institution where you work, according to you, how developed are the protocol

activities for work, appropriate organizational set-up in relation to the overall orga-

nization of the institution)? Is it necessary to unite the capacities in protocol, from all

related institutions in the form of United State Protocol?, a fairly adequate picture

can be obtained of the level of development of the protocol capacities in each of the

institutions - President, Assembly, Government, Ministries (Ministry of Defense,

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

Ministry of Interior, Ministry of Foreign Affairs) and Army. Additionally, the opinion

was rounded off with the possibility to answer several additional questions, of which

the issue of the need to create a Unified State Protocol is of particular importance.

Overall, the opinion of the experts in the field of protocol coming from the

private sector, regarding the issue of creating a United State Protocol is unified and

extremely positive towards this possibility. “Protocol capacities should be merged into

a single state protocol, in order to pool knowledge, resources, ensure more efficient

coordination and communication, as well as continuity of work,” said one respondent

from this group.

In the context of the current capacities of the institutions, starting from the

highest legislative house, the Assembly of the Republic of North Macedonia, it is seen

that the opinion prevails among these respondents that although there is a separate 5

protocol unit in the form of a department, it is not always sufficiently filled and fully

functional, which affects the efficiency of protocol support, which is extremely im-

portant in this institution.

Respondents from the institution President, focus more on the need for or-

ganizational change in the way the protocol units operate through the state adminis-

tration, than on the information about the current capacity of the organizational unit

for protocol in this institution. Their common conclusion is that “the protocol should

be united”, “unique”, “harmonized”, i.e. to take the form of a “united state protocol”.

Respondents from the group of employees in the Government of the Republic

of North Macedonia, point out that there is always a need for additional staff within

the protocol, because it is an organizational unit that faces a continuous number of

activities that require full commitment and constant vigilance. They largely agree

with the need to create a single state protocol, under the auspices of the Government,

which would coordinate and organize major events of importance to the state.

“There should be a united state protocol and it should be under the auspices

of the Government as the highest executive body, but also to be organized as a cap of

all other protocol units in other institutions. It should be the body that would issue the

guidelines and principles of work, while the execution would be to some extent dele-

gated to the protocol units themselves,” said a government employee. His colleague

adds that the creation of a United State Protocol will solve a number of problems. “I

think that such an integrative solution would solve many specific problems and chal-

lenges - lack of finances, waste of resources, staffing of ministries, lack of coordination,

unnecessary gaffes that destroy credibility, and it would almost certainly increase the

country’s reputation. This stems from some basic principles of organizational theory,

as well as the needs of a small country like Macedonia. Centralization and integration

of capacities in the form of “streamlining” in one sphere of activity of the organization

increases the efficiency in that sphere, by paying attention to potential side effects

such as undesirable concentration of power and influence that they follow every

centralization,” he said.

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

Respondents from perhaps the most concerned ministry, if we talk about

general diplomacy, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, are vocal when it comes to the

need to establish a united state protocol, under the auspices of the Ministry of Foreign

Affairs, which according to them is the natural environment for such a capacity. To a

large extent, they also see the already existing organizational unit in the Ministry of

Foreign Affairs dedicated to the protocol, the Directorate for Diplomatic Protocol, as

a form of state protocol.

“In the Ministry of Foreign Affairs there is a Directorate for Diplomatic Protocol,

headed by a Director, an experienced diplomat, two assistant directors, experienced

“protocol officers” and a relatively solid staffing in terms of executors. The protocol

of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has so far functioned prominently and successfully

responds to all anticipated and unforeseen situations that often know to occur,” said

a respondent from the Ministry. The point of view of his colleague from the same in-

stitution corresponds completely - the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as an institution is

the bearer and main coordinator of the protocol activities of the state, due to which in

many countries there is so-called state protocol established in this ministry is, which at

the same time takes into account the political aspects of its activities.” “I have always

advocated for the establishment of a single State Protocol under the auspices of the

Ministry of Foreign Affairs, with small logistics offices in appropriate state institutions,”

said one respondent, and his female colleague added that “within one state protocol,

led by an experienced person In the area of protocol, there should be three separate

organizational units - a protocol of the President, a protocol of the Prime Minister

and a protocol of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The goal is to strengthen capacity,

and respond more effectively to tasks and needs.”

The respondents from the Ministry of Interior are familiar with the fact that in

their institution there is an organizational unit for protocol, some of them fully know

its organizational setup, structure and completeness, and some can testify that the

protocol activities are realized, but have no information whether this department is

facing difficulties or not.

“In the Ministry of Interior, the protocol activities are set at a high level and

really take a special place in the hierarchy of the Ministry and are respected by those

for whom they are intended. In the Department of Public Relations and Strategic

Issues, within the Sector for Public Relations and Protocol, there is a Unit for protocol

events and activities, which is headed by a chief and four executives who perform

tasks related to organizing ministerial meetings, international forums and meetings,

by providing professional and logistical support for their successful implementation,

preparation and implementation of working meetings and visits to representatives

of foreign countries, international organizations and associations, etc.,” said one re-

spondent from this Ministry.

This group of respondents believes that the protocol activities are implement-

ed in a more than satisfactory way and most of them are relatively skeptical of what

could result in improvement if a united state protocol is created. “The united state

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

protocol has its advantages - it is guided by one point - but, in my opinion, this type of

organization also has its serious disadvantage - centralization of activities. However,

I agree that as a minimum it is necessary to establishone point that will perform a

unique and consistent training of all protocol officers within the institutions.

One hundred percent of the respondents from the Ministry of Defense are

aware that there is an organizational unit for protocol in their institution, and many

of them know exactly in which segment this unit exists - as a Department for protocol

and translation in the Sector for Communications, Analytics and Operational Support

in the Ministry.

They generally agree that there is a need for additional staffing and further

training of the staff in this unit, which in fact will undergo a change in its position

according to the new structural structure of the Ministry, which is currently under 5

analysis. Despite the positive comments in the context of this change, one respondent

explicitly disagrees with it and says: “that formulation for separating the protocol

as something primitive is old. It should be seen in modern times as part of strategic

communications, as it is currently set. However, there is room for discussion about

organizational set-up and it can be improved. It’s important that staff follow modern

trends.”

There are also respondents who believe that there is a need for a more detailed

definition of procedures and rules. “It is necessary for the protocol as an organizational

unit to have more independence and more legitimacy, i.e. credibility in the institution,”

said one respondent, and another added that “unfortunately, there are no organiza-

tional procedures and procedures” and that “most of the current activities are realized

thanks to more experienced employees who have performed such responsible tasks

in the past.” According to him, these are ad-hoc solutions, improvisations burdened

with subjectivism, personal views or orders from superiors that do not correspond to

the real and necessary procedures, measures and activities.

Regarding the possibility of merging all protocol units in the form of a United

State Protocol, opinions are divided - one part agrees that this is the right way for-

ward, and another part points to some specifics that were mentioned earlier. “In the

Ministry of Defense of the Republic of North Macedonia, the protocol service should

be reorganized and adequately supplemented with trained personnel, but unification

is not necessary due to the specifics of the military protocol. But of course, there

is a need for better coordination with the state protocol, says a respondent from

the Ministry of Defense.

Perhaps the most familiar with the protocol activities and the way the proto-

col is organized in their institution are the respondents employed in the Army of the

Republic of North Macedonia, who besides being familiar with the fact that there is

a separate organizational structure of the military protocol, most of them are aware

that there is a Military Protocol Rule, according to which it operates. Interestingly,

although Army respondents believe that tasks are accomplished efficiently, they

question whether efficiency may increase if a fusion is first made between the two

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

different organizational units for protocol between the Ministry of Defense and the

Army, before moving on to the possibility of establishing a state protocol. The dilem-

mas are of a familiar nature - the centralization of such an institution, its bulkiness,

the huge number of activities, and even the specifics of the military protocol.

“In the MoD and the General Staff of the Army, there are separate protocol

organizational units that do not have a large number of personnel. In the Army there

is a rulebook/rule for protocol activities during celebrations and ceremonies of the

units. Greater cooperation between the protocol and security institutions is needed

for coordinated engagement. When it comes to the United State Protocol as an

institution in which the capacities of the protocol from other institutions would be

merged, I think thatit would be too centralized institution that will not be able to

function successfully if the processes are not developed, or they are decentralized.

It would have a much greater effect if that institution is an umbrella - an institution

that will take care of defining the procedures, improving the processes, uniforming the

procedures and an organization that will have an educational/supervisory character,”

said an Army respondent.

2.13. The role of protocol in the effectiveness of defense diplomacy

From the analysis so far, we have identified several important elements related

to the inextricable link between protocol and diplomacy. We saw that the thinking of

the respondents goes in the direction that there is a connection between the protocol

and defense diplomacy and that within the institutions this type of capacity in the

field of protocol exists and to some extent is developing.

But does the protocol affect the effectiveness of defense diplomacy? That is,

just as the question was left in the interviews – “To what extent do protocol rules play

a role in the efficiency of the implementation of the activities of defense diplomacy

and why?“.

“The protocol is a basic thread in diplomacy, as well as in the military, because

it is a set of rules and procedures that are internationally accepted as an expression

of mutual diplomatic courtesy. They express the respect, esteem and importance of

international relations. No part of diplomacy, including defense, can survive without

protocol as a separate form of diplomatic interaction,” said a private sector respondent.

Most of the respondents from the Ministry of Defense agree with this opinion and

consider that the protocol activities are an important component in the realization of

certain activities, especially “events of high or ceremonial character”. If the protocol

does not work as intended, “the state may be perceived as inefficient, unstable, and

thus insecure.” It is interesting that from the aspect of security there is another con-

notation – “The protocol plays a direct role in terms of security, because the people in

this area are in direct, constant and direct contact with the leadership, which from a

security point of view means that if they are compromised, compromised is an entire

institution.”

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

Of course, there are respondents who believe that there is no direct correlation

between the effective implementation of defense diplomacy and the protocol. One

such respondent from the area of defense said: “[the role played by the protocol rules

in terms of the efficiency of the implementation of the activities of defense diplomacy]

is partial, to significant extent. It should not be forgotten that this is changing given

the informal meetings and communication through social networks which increasingly

enable ad-hoc communication and exchange of views.”

Respondents from the Ministry of the Interior, for example, are more inclined to

conclude that the protocol affects the effectiveness of diplomacy, including defensive

diplomacy. “By respecting the protocol rules, the individual image of the institution

and the state is built, possible unpleasant situations are avoided, better communica-

tions are achieved, greater professionalism is achieved,” said a respondent from the 5

Ministry of Interior. This can be followed by the opinion of his colleague who says that

ignorance or non-compliance with the protocol rules can lead to a diplomatic scandal

that can disrupt well-established interstate relations.”

2.14. Protocol and security

The respondents, most of whom have really vast experience in their workplace,

were directly asked for their opinion regarding the connection between protocol and

security. The question was: “Can it be said that the protocol, as an interdisciplinary

field that has its share in diplomacy/defense diplomacy, directly affects the security

of the country? If so, to what extent? If not, why not?”

The analysis of all the interviews gives a clear distinction in the thinking of the

respondents who have largely similar positions, but there are also individual interesting

conclusions from a different perspective.

Namely, a huge number of respondents believe that there is an inseparable

link between the protocol and security. In this “camp” the biggest division is whether

this “unbreakable connection” is direct or indirect, although the elements on which

one or the other reasoning is based are practically very similar, with the difference

that each individual responds differently to the meaning of these elements.

A small number of respondents believe that there is no connection between

the protocol and security, while a third and the smallest see the protocol as a tool for

gathering relevant information for the needs of security services.

From a quantitative point of view, two thirds of the respondents say that the

connection between the protocol and security is direct or indirect. Of the respondents

who say that the connection between the protocol and security is direct, most are

employees of the Army of the Republic of North Macedonia, the Ministry of Defense

and the Ministry of Interior and formulated their opinion through the experience

gained during the work.

Proponents of the opinion that the protocol is directly and essentially affecting

the security, support this through the fact that “the protocol strengthens international

relations, conflicts, scandals and anything that could harm the relationship with the

DIPLOMACY, PROTOCOL AND SAFETY

international partner are avoided.” In addition, it can be said that the direct connection

refers to the fact that every performance of a diplomat is not seen as the performance

of the individual, but of the country he or she represents. “The protocol directly af-

fects the security of the state from the aspect that if certain protocol standards are

not observed, certain states can understand it as their degradation, disrespect and

contribute to a complete change of behavior, diplomatic relations and security of the

state as a whole,” says one respondent from the area of defense. An interesting fact

is related to the opinion that if the protocol had been fully followed, the assassina-

tion of the first president of Macedonia, Kiro Gligorov would not have been even half

successful, i.e. if the former president Gligorov, according to the protocol rules, was

sitting in the back seat, he would not have suffered serious injuries, as was the case, as

a passenger in the front passenger seat. The aspect of security and the possibility of

encroachment on the lives of foreign officials is also taken as a challenge that burdens

interstate relations, and is attributed to the link between protocol and security. The

hypothetical situation in which a certain statesman, due to non-compliance with the

strict protocol rules, is assassinated while visiting another country, can very easily

cause serious incidents and even conflict between these two countries.

Proponents of the idea that these two areas are indirectly related base their

views on several perspectives. Academics say “although in a more direct sense the

protocol does not seem to have a significant impact on security, if we look deeper into

the specific political circumstances, the slightest political gaffe, whether intentional

or not, could mean disturbed diplomatic relations and even a war.” This is how the

Serbian public interprets the gaffes during the celebration of the 100th anniversary

of the First World War, but also the recent signing of the agreement between Serbia

and the United States and Kosovo with the United States, when President Aleksandar

Vuќiќ was inappropriately placed in front of US President Trump, who was clearly in a

dominant position. The same applies to protocol mistakes in placing flags (other coun-

tries, inappropriate emblems, etc.), which can cause intra-state security challenges,

but also inter-state disagreements, sparks, and even open conflict. Protocol can be

so subtle, but also so brutal. Practically speaking, mistakes in the protocol can lead

to endangering the life of the foreign representative (or accompanying staff) through

traffic risks, insults from citizens in the host country, inadequate nutrition and the like.

Non-compliance with the protocol rules can lead to “disruption of security relations

between the two countries - expulsion of mutually attached attachés, non-ratification

of their agreements, non-compliance with peace or post-conflict agreements and the

like.” And, although 100 percent of the group of respondents who say that the impact

is indirect, clearly indicate that there is no direct connection, they did not forgot to

mention that non-compliance with the procedures can cause disruption of relations

and, cascading, cause withdrawal of cooperation, which will lead to a deterioration of the

security situation, especially for countries like ours, whose absolute security depends

on collective security. Of course, we should not forget the image of a country - if it has

a dysfunctional protocol, it can be perceived as inefficient, unstable, and thus unsafe.

Defense diplomacy and the protocol in in achievement of security

- results from the research

The smaller number of supporters of the opinion that there is no correlation

between the protocol and security, do not give a more comprehensive reason why they

defined their point of view, although according to one of them “the security of the state

does not depend on the effectiveness of the protocol. He is the first person foreigners

see when they come to our country, but diplomacy, including defense diplomacy, is

the tool that builds and maintains the security of the country inside and outside“.

The third view suggests that the protocol is in fact “the first access to the

information before the event happens and the target served.” The persons working in

the protocol must have knowledge of the intelligence activities in order to be able to

collect data, to establish a network of contacts, to determine the specifics of behavior

of each person who makes decisions, and the same is important from a counter-in-

telligence point of view, for the purposes of - protection of the information at their 5

disposal.

2.15. Specifics of the protocol: Macedonian institutions

The protocol organizational units within the Macedonian institutions have their

own specifics, which was a kind of initial trigger to seek the opinion of respondents

who have really great experience working in the public sector.

The question they were asked was: “What would be the specifics of the protocol

in the Macedonian institutions (related to this organizational unit in the institution

you come from)?”

The opinion coming from a respondent outside the institutions is in the di-

rection that “the Macedonian protocol is still ‘stuck’ given the limited resources and

staff.” She adds that this service does not receive the necessary institutional and

material support it needs. “The lack of a united state protocol can sometimes create

problems, as well as the lack of investing in the staff, the lack of staff and the general

lack of understanding of the importance of this service by both the public and the

statesmen, which of course creates conditions for making mistakes.”

An executive respondent for the Macedonian protocol says that it is decentral-
